metadata.title: Effect of Vacuum Plasma Activation on Early Implant Stability: a Single-Blind Split-Mouth Randomized Clinical Trial Claudio Stacchi1, Antonio Rapani1, Marco Montanari2, Rebecca Martini1, Teresa Lombardi3 Department of Medical, Surgical and Health Sciences, University of Trieste, 34100 Trieste, Italy.
metadata.journal: Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Research

introduction.heading: Introduction
introduction.first_sentence: Modern implant designs have undergone extensive improvement over the past decades, with particular emphasis on optimizing surface morphology, chemistry, and macro-geometry to promote osseointegration and enhance clinical outcomes [1-3].

discussion.heading: Discussion
discussion.first_sentence: The present split-mouth randomized controlled clinical trial aimed to evaluate the effect of vacuum plasma treatment on early implant stability in partially edentulous patients.
discussion.first_100_chars: The present split-mouth randomized controlled clinical trial aimed to evaluate the effect of vacuum
discussion.last_sentence: Future large-scale, multicenter clinical trials with extended follow-up are warranted to determine whether these differences translate into meaningful clinical advantages, such as earlier loading or improved longterm outcomes.

conclusions.heading: Conclusions
conclusions.first_sentence: Within the limitations of this randomized controlled clinical trial, the findings suggest that vacuum plasma treatment of titanium implants, applied immediately before placement, may positively influence implant stability during the intermediate phas
conclusions.first_100_chars: Within the limitations of this randomized controlled clinical trial, the findings suggest that vacuu
conclusions.last_sentence: Future studies could explore whether combining plasma activation with minimally invasive site preparation methods may further optimize early implant stability, particularly in more challenging clinical scenarios.
